title: How to Deal With Your Hamster Dying

steps.title: Recognize the signs.
steps.content: Recognize the signs. There are many reasons that may claim the life of your hamster. Old age, for example, may make your hamster’s eyes go dull. You may notice his fur getting thin. It may make your hamster listless and cause his appetite to disappear. Your hamster may exhibit unusual signs, such as urinating in its nest. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Talk to someone who can help.
steps.content: Talk to someone who can help. Your parents may be able to offer advice on how to help your hamster. You may be able to talk to an experienced professional, like a vet, for more specific details on how to care for your hamster. She will give you advice on diet, exercise, and care.

steps.title: Consider your hamster's suffering.
steps.content: Consider your hamster's suffering. If your hamster in too much pain, you may want to consider other options. Euthanasia may be the best option to stop his suffering. This is a painless process and the professionals will do what they can to make the last stages of your pet’s life as comfortable as possible. steps.title: Prepare your friends and family.
steps.content: Prepare your friends and family. You want to tell those close to you about what is going to happen. This may be your child’s first experience with death, and you want to approach it with care. Be honest and approach with empathy. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Make your hamster comfortable.
steps.content: Make your hamster comfortable. In your hamster’s last days, make him as happy as possible. Put soft material in his cage. Let him sleep as much as he wants. Put his favorite toys in his cage.

steps.title: Avoid excessive holding.
steps.content: Avoid excessive holding. Your hamster may lose energy and may not participate in its usual exercise. You do not want to make him excessively tired by holding him.

steps.title: Feed and water appropriately.
steps.content: Feed and water appropriately. Talk to your vet or parents about what diet would be best. If your hamster is suffering from heart damage, for example, you may want to avoid fatty foods like sunflowers. Teeth issues can also plague older hamsters. Try feeding him soft foods like rice or cereal.

steps.title: Acknowledge your grief for the loss of your hamster.
steps.content: Acknowledge your grief for the loss of your hamster. You are going to be upset and are going to hurt. You might feel strong emotions like anger, grief, depression, or guilt. It is okay to feel these strong feelings after a loss of a loved one. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Take some time.
steps.content: Take some time. Your hamster was a part of your family and you will need time to grieve. Consider taking time off work or school to feel your grief. Statistics show that the pain you feel when you lose a pet is akin to losing a human family member. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Talk to friends and family.
steps.content: Talk to friends and family. Your loved ones probably are aware of how much you loved your hamster. They can help you through the grieving process if you reach out to them. Talk to them about what you are feeling, and they may help to ease the passing. Reader Poll: We asked 172 wikiHow readers how they cope with the loss of a pet, and 56% of them said that they share the feelings with friends or family members . [Take Poll]

steps.title: Memorialize your hamster.
steps.content: Memorialize your hamster. Remember the positive things about your friend. You can go through pictures of your pet. You can think about the games and toys you played with him. These good things may make your grief a little less painful.

steps.title: Write out your feelings.
steps.content: Write out your feelings. You can start a blog or journal. Writing out your feelings may help you work out your grief. You can write about the positive memories and thoughts of your beloved family member. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Reach out to resources.
steps.content: Reach out to resources. There are national resources you can reach out to if you need someone to talk to you. Reaching out to resources like the ASPCA hotline can connect you to people who understand. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Volunteer at a local shelter.
steps.content: Volunteer at a local shelter. Once you start the healing process, you might hesitate to bring a new hamster into your home. You can volunteer at a local animal shelter to help others in need. Helping animals in need might help you with the grief process.

steps.title: Look for a new friend.
steps.content: Look for a new friend. After you start to heal, you may feel up to bringing in a new hamster. Visit your local shelter or pet store for a new addition to your family.

steps.title: Get back to a regular routine.
steps.content: Get back to a regular routine. To fully move on, it might be best to get back to your day to day schedule. It might hurt for a while, but if you take one day at a time, you will find that your grief lessens. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Remember it will be alright.
steps.content: Remember it will be alright. Everyone experience loss, know that you are not alone with your loss. This may be a very hard time for you, but things will get better. Remember these steps and take time to grieve your loss.
